metadata.case_name: Defendants 8 to 11 v. Respondents Nos. 1 to 3

facts.text: Dispute relates to land measuring 179 kanals and 2 marlas in village Wanderjatana.
On August 26, 1949, defendants 3 to 7 sold the said land to defendants 1 and 2 for Rs. 37,611.
On August 26, 1950, defendants 8 to 11 (appellants) instituted Suit No. 231 of 1950 in Court of Subordinate Judge, 11 Class, Faridkot, to pre-empt the sale.

On January 6, 1951, vendees (defendants 1 and 2) and plaintiffs in Suit 231 (defendants 8 to 11) entered into compromise. Vendees admitted receiving Rs. 1,700; balance Rs. 35,911 to be paid by April 27, 1951, for possession through court.
Compromise deed filed in District Judge court; decree dated January 23, 1951, providing for dismissal if balance not paid by April 27, 1951.
Defendants 8 to 11 deposited Rs. 35,911 on April 23, 1951, and got possession on May 17, 1951.

Before deposit, respondents (owners in same patti) filed Suit No. 13 of 1951 on February 15, 1951, in Subordinate Judge, Faridkot, to enforce pre-emption right. Impleaded original vendors (3-7), vendees (1-2), and Suit 231 plaintiffs (8-11).
Subordinate Judge dismissed respondents' suit, finding defendants 8-11 became vendees through court decree before rivals' suit.
Additional District Judge, Faridkot, in Civil Appeal No. 10/1952, held equal rights, entitled to shares 3/7 and 4/7 proportionately.
High Court of Patiala and East Punjab States Union (PEPSU) in R.S.A. Nos. 57 and 130 of 1952 upheld shares but remanded on amount paid in good faith and s.17C(e). Judgment dated April 29, 1953.
Appellants obtained special leave for Supreme Court appeal.

legal_issues.text: Whether appellants (defendants 8-11), having obtained compromise decree, deposited money, and taken possession before respondents' suit completion, defeated respondents' equal pre-emption right, or if respondents entitled to share under s.17 Punjab Pre-emption Act.
Whether s.28 requires both suits pending for sharing under s.17, and if appellants exercised right by decree/deposit, requiring superior right from respondents.
Applicability of lis pendens to substitution pendente lite.

petitioner_arguments.text: Section 28 indicates property divided between equal pre-emptors under s.17 only when both suits pending at decree time.
Appellants exercised pre-emption by obtaining decree or depositing money, substituted in place of vendees; respondents need superior right.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: General law of pre-emption; right of substitution

petitioner_arguments.text: Compromise decree clothed them with title.

respondent_arguments.text: Equal pre-emptors have statutory right under s.17 to share land; appellants substituted pendente lite, hit by lis pendens, cannot claim higher rights than original vendees.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Section 17 Punjab Pre-emption Act; doctrine of lis pendens

court_reasoning.text: Right of pre-emption is primary right to offer, secondary remedial right of substitution for whole property, not share; requires superior right over vendee or substitute.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Preference essence; weak right defeated by legitimate substitution of equal/superior pre-emptor.

court_reasoning.text: Punjab Pre-emption Act does not enlarge right; s.13 allows joint/several exercise of whole right; s.17 for distribution only if equally entitled and right yet to be exercised.
court_reasoning.key_observation: s.17 applies where right yet to be exercised; not against one already substituted.

court_reasoning.text: s.28 procedural for joining suits, does not affect substantive rights; separate decree valid if substitution effectuated.
Lis pendens applies to pre-emption suits but not to transfer recognizing subsisting pre-existing right; appellants' right subsisting via suit, decree, deposit within time.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Appellants not hit by lis pendens; acquired indefeasible right on possession after deposit.

court_reasoning.text: Conditional compromise decree effects substitution only on compliance and possession; not before.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Pre-emptor substituted only on fulfilling decree terms.

holdings.text: Appellants, by obtaining decree, depositing amount, and taking possession, legitimately substituted in place of original vendees with indefeasible right; respondents' equal right defeated.
Doctrine of lis pendens does not apply to appellants' substitution as their pre-emptive right was subsisting and enforceable.
Punjab Pre-emption Act provisions procedural; do not create right to share against prior substituted equal pre-emptor.

precedents_cited.relevance: Defines primary and secondary rights of pre-emption.
Secondary right is right of substitution.
No right to share; superior right needed; lis pendens in pre-emption.

precedents_cited.case_name: Mt. Sant Kaur v. Teja Singh
precedents_cited.relevance: Lis pendens limitation for subsisting pre-emptive rights.
Lis pendens applies if right barred.

precedents_cited.case_name: Wazir Ali Khan v. Zahir Ahmad Khan
precedents_cited.relevance: Transfer pendente lite subject to suit unless recognizing subsisting right.

precedents_cited.case_name: Deonandan Prashad Singh v. Ramdhari Chowdhri
precedents_cited.relevance: Substitution only on payment and possession under decree.

statutes_cited.name: Punjab Pre-emption Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines right, procedure for exercise, sharing among equals only if right yet to be exercised, joining suits.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court allowed the appeal by special leave, holding that appellants (defendants 8-11) had perfected their pre-emption right through compromise decree, deposit, and possession, defeating respondents' equal claim; no share under s.17.
outcome.relief_granted: Appellants' right to entire land upheld; respondents' suit defeated.

key_quotes.text: "The right of pre-emption is not a right to the thing sold but a right to the offer of a thing about to be sold."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "It is a right of substitution but not of re-purchase, i.e., the pre-emptor takes the entire bargain and steps into the shoes of the original vendee."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core incident of secondary right; no sharing.

key_quotes.text: "Preference being the essence of the right, the plaintiff must have a superior right to that of the vendee or the person substituted in his place."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "The appellants are not hit by the doctrine of lis pendens and they acquired an indefeasible right to the suit land."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key holding on lis pendens applicability.
